As you know, we're here at this conference talking about open educational resources and and what open educational resources provides a lot of Accessibility, primarily driven by financial considerations also really empowers us as educators to produce our own content, because it makes sharing so much easier.
We're no longer locked into a lot of Copyright issues that restrict our work.

But in fact, with that open license that comes with open educational resources, we can modify resources to add Accessibility features such as captions to videos, alternative image, text to images within our presentation, so that for students who use screen readers, they can read those.
So open educational resources an Accessibility go hand in hand, you would think.
And that is of course the overall goal, but we know that it's never as easy as we think it will.

This is the definition agreed to by UNESCO and also by many private foundations throughout the world that support we are so teaching, learning or research materials that are in the public domain or released with an intellectual property license that allows free use, adoption and distribution, and so that intellectual property license is really key because public domain varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, so it's not.
And we might ask you later in the day about that, how it works in Australia, how it works in Slovenia.
